comment: Absolutely well done and definitely keep it up!!! 👍👍👍👍👍
She looks like aged Brie Larson.

17:28  "Reduction" should not have made it past the disambiguation police. Its usage here is wholly inconsistent with how chemistry students have already been trained for years to see Cl- as a chlorine that's gained an electron (filling the octet so Cl - is unable to oxidize anything in its Cl- state, yet it retains the initial -1 oxidant value of a neutral Cl). Chemists should have used a new word or applied a foreign word in place of reduce. If there is a solid practical application supporting the usage of "Reduce" then some history or practical observations should have been used first laying the foundation for introducing the new usage-meaning with an eye for ambiguity of usage to students.

She is a great Chemistry teacher, but even a high school physics student would correct her in that the flow of electrons in the wire does not cause the Voltage. The potential difference in energy (the difference in Gibbs free energy) is the potential which is measured and causes the current (flow of electrons) in the wire (ignoring resistance losses)
Good Job! I love how she explains the concepts. It makes me understand the lessons faster and easier. Thanks a lot! :)
this professor is smart. i love her enthusiasm and intelligence
to err is human,and to correct someone  with humbleness so that she/he doesnt feel intimidated is intelligence. i am very bad at it.

To understand how communication between two people that are practical strangers with asymmetric background knowledge of the topic being discussed becomes a practical impossibility is... throws dart at word-of-the-day calendar
